parallel.distributed

Class PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorSrv

  • java.lang.Object
    • parallel.distributed.PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorSrv

  • public final class PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorSrv
extends java.lang.Object
    Server class allows clients or workers to connect to this process and submit TaskObjects for asynchronous processing to any of the available workers in the network of connected workers. A worker process connects to this process on default port 7980 and by doing so declares itself available for processing an array of TaskObject objects, encapsulated in a TaskObjectsAsynchExecutionRequest. The server then expects clients to connect to its clients-listening port (default 7981) for requests to serve. The server may also become itself client to another server in the network, and if this is the case, then, whenever another client submits a request, if the workers connected to this server are all busy, it will try submitting the request to the other server to which it is a client (unless the other server is also the client that originated or forwarded the request) until it gets a response. This ability means that servers can (and should) form ring topologies, instead of simple chains. Notice that in this implementation, if a worker fails to run a batch job, it is removed from the pool of available workers, and the connection to it is closed. For details see the method PDAsynchBTEWListener.runObject( TaskObjectsAsynchExecutionRequest req). Further, the server can be started with the option of sending to all workers connecting to it, an "initialization command", which assuming the workers are also run with the option of accepting first this init-cmd, they will run it before starting their thread-pool (so that the initialization is known to the threads in the thread-pool). This initialization command, in the form of an PDAsynchInitCmd, will have to arrive from a client connected to the server before any worker has connected to this server (this is contrary to the design of PDBTExec[Inited[Clt|Wrk]|SingleCltWrkInitSrv] classes where the workers and single client may connect to the server in any order.) Any worker connecting to the server before a client has specified the initialization command, the worker will pause until a client specifies the init-cmd, which is then sent to the worker; during this time, the server does not respond to worker incoming socket connection requests. The full Computing Policies are as follows: Upon receiving (from a client) a batch of tasks to be executed, the server polls each of its currently known workers (in parallel if the server has been started with the boolean flag "poll_workers_concurrently" which is the 4-th argument of the command-line set to true) for their availability by asking for the total number of idle threads they have, and also for the number of tasks they have completed so far. If it polls workers in parallel, the server simply finds the "best" worker (which is the worker with the most idle threads if there is at least one such, or else the worker with the best ratio of tasks-submitted versus tasks-in-queue) and submits the tasks to it. If the server polls workers serially, after it finds the first "free" (having idle thread) worker, the server only polls up to _MAX_WIN_POLL_ATTEMPTS workers to find a better one. The above process occurs up to _NUM_ATTEMPTS times or until a free (with at least 1 idle thread) worker is found. In case the result of this process is a non-free worker, if there exists another known server to this one (whose ip and port are specified as the last 2 arguments in the command-line that started up this server), the tasks are sent to this other known server to distribute to its own workers, unless the tasks actually originated from this other known server!, in which case, the server will distribute the tasks to its own workers. If a worker connection is lost during processing a batch of tasks, the batch will be re-submitted once more to the next available worker, as soon as such a worker becomes available. Similarly, if a worker fails to process a batch of tasks and returns a FailedReply object back to this server, the server will attempt one more time to re-submit the batch to another worker as soon as such a worker becomes available and drops its connection from this "loser" worker. If the same batch of jobs fails to be executed by two different workers, the server sends back to the client that submitted the job, a FailedReply to indicate the job cannot be successfully completed.

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2017

    Company:

    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou

        Parameters:
        wport - int the port workers (PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorWrk) connect to
        cport - int the port clients (PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorClt) connect to
        sendinitcmd - boolean sets the appropriate flag
        pollworkersconcurrently - boolean if true, creates the appropriate executor with 10 threads for polling workers concurrently

      • submitWork

        void submitWork(java.util.Vector originating_clients,
                TaskObject[] tasks)
         throws java.io.IOException,
                java.lang.ClassNotFoundException,
                PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorException
        searches (up to _NUM_ATTEMPTS times) among all its worker connections, to find a connection to the worker with the most free threads. In each iteration, if the best worker connection reports at least one free thread, it sends the tasks to this connection. Otherwise, it tries to send the tasks to the connection to the other known server, if it has one such connection, and if the tasks were not submitted from this other server. If this isn't possible either, it sends the tasks to this known worker to be running (even though currently busy) that has gotten the best (max) ratio of tasks accepted thus far over num tasks in its current queue. Otherwise, it throws PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorException, which propagates to client who reads a NoWorkerAvailableResponse response object, and in turn throws PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorNWAException from the PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorClt.submitWork*() methods. Notice that by this method, in the long run, optimal load balancing is expected (in the face of unknown task execution times), since it is always the lightest loaded worker that will get the tasks to be executed. To counter the drawback in the face of many workers connected to this server, that is, that it polls all of them to find the best one, the method only polls up to _MAX_WIN_POLL_ATTEMPTS workers after it has found a free worker (this remark is true only when the server is started with the flag for polling workers concurrently set to false(default)). Method is only called from RRObject objects. NOT part of the public API.
        Parameters:
        originating_clients - Vector // Vector<PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorClt>
        tasks - TaskObject[]
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException
        PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorException

      • addNewClientConnection

        private void addNewClientConnection(java.net.Socket s,
                                    long id)
        adds a new client to the network. The difference between clients and workers is that "clients" submit jobs to the network, but don't want to "get" any job to do themselves. Workers may also submit jobs to the network but are also available to run tasks themselves as well.
        Parameters:
        s - Socket
        id - long

      • updateMaxNumTasksPerWorker

        private PDAsynchBatchTaskExecutorSrv.PDAsynchBTEWListener updateMaxNumTasksPerWorker()
        search through the entire hash-map for the worker with the most tasks, and return this worker listener, updating the related cache value (_maxNumTasksPerWorker) as well.
        Returns:
        PDAsynchBTEWListener may be null

        Returns:
